Award.AwardTitle: Research Coordination Network-Undergraduate Biology Education: Promoting Active Learning & Mentoring (PALM) Incubator Program
Award.AbstractNarration:
The American Society for Cell Biology, in collaboration with the American Society for Plant Biology and the Genetics Society of America, has received a Research Coordination Network - Undergraduate Biology Education award for their project entitled Promoting Active Learning & Mentoring (PALM). This project is forming a network to promote Vision and Change-guided reforms in undergraduate teaching and learning through effective, long-term professional development. Long-term mentorships are being organized between faculty and postdoctoral fellows (PALM Fellows) seeking to learn pedagogical best practices and faculty mentors who have already transformed their classrooms with effective active learning strategies.

PALM Fellows visit the classrooms of their mentors and participate in redesigned classes on the mentor's campus. Based on this experience, and guided by their mentors, PALM Fellows restructure all, or a portion, of one of their own classes using effective, active learning pedagogies. Fellows are required to report their findings to the scientific community and will be invited to become mentors when they have acquired several years of experience in their own classrooms. The Classroom Observation Protocol for Undergraduate STEM (COPUS), which involves direct observation of classroom pedagogies, is being used in project evaluation to measure the progress of the PALM Fellows, as well as the effectiveness of the program. The results of the project evaluation are advancing our knowledge of best practice in faculty professional development through mentoring. This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to improve undergraduate biology education by providing a substantive and prolonged mentoring experience for instructors who wanted to learn how to incorporate more active learning into their lecture classes. We had three major goals.

The first goal of this project was to create a core network of professional societies that would work to promote and support this type of professional development for their members.  We began our network as a collaborative effort among societies for scientists in the fields of cell biology, genetics, and plant biology, and have added societies whose members work in the fields of physiology and microbiology and to support underrepresented students in science.  We have reached out also to groups that do biology education research, biochemistry and molecular biology, neuroscience, bioinformatics, and other groups who work to integrate science and math, to help promote awareness of our program and recruit new Fellows and mentors.

The next goal involved establishing the mentoring program for instructors and for postdoctoral students who wanted to prepare for a career that involves teaching.  We devised an application process, advertised the opportunity, and selected six PALM Fellows and their mentors, who were experienced in evidence-based active learning approaches.  Each PALM Fellow/mentor pair worked one-on-one for six to nine months on a specific area that the Fellow wanted to modify to include more active learning.  The project provided travel funds to visit the mentor to observe the mentor's teaching and have focused discussions about how to modify the Fellow's teaching practice.  Further interaction occurred by phone and teleconference meetings and at PALM Gatherings held twice a year in conjunction with meetings of professional biology societies or college level teaching societies.  All Fellows and mentors were expected attend at least one professional society meeting to tell colleagues about the changes they made in their classrooms and about the PALM program in general, as a way to spread awareness of the program and the positive effects active learning can have on student learning.  Each Fellow submitted a video recording of his/her teaching before and after the initial mentoring period.  A trained observer analyzed the instructor and student activities on the video according to a protocol designed specifically to determine various types of active learning.  These data provided material for further discussion and mentoring on how to achieve the desired improvements in the Fellow's teaching practice.

The final goal of the project was to establish a Steering Committee to carry out tasks such as advising on design of the PALM website, flyers, and application materials, reviewing Fellowship applications, and working to expand the network of professional societies involved.  Our Steering Committee consists of a mixture of representatives from scientific professional societies and faculty members who have experience in active learning, in mentoring other instructors in the use of active learning, in assessment procedures, and in promoting professional development programs.
